clean_story:
Past moments.  Time’s shadow.


"Why memory feels like time" describes how our brains stitch stored experiences into the sensation of a flowing past.

Memory isn’t a filing cabinet—it’s a reconstruction site.
When you recall yesterday’s breakfast, your brain reassembles fragments: the smell of coffee, the clink of a spoon, the light through the window.
This rebuilding takes effort—like replaying a song from scattered notes.

The "feel" of time comes from two tricks:

First, order. Memories link like paper clips—each one hooks to the next.
If you remember your morning commute, it’s not one image but a chain: locking the door—stepping outside—hearing the bus.
Second, decay. Older memories fade like footprints in sand.
A childhood birthday feels "far away" because details blur—just the cake’s color remains, not the taste.

Here’s the twist: time doesn’t cause this feeling—memory does.
Your brain isn’t reading a timeline; it’s guessing one from clues.
Ever noticed how a vivid dream feels like hours, but checks only minutes? That’s your memory stretching thin.

Three related subjects are how sleep reshapes memories,  false memories’ hidden triggers,  and why nostalgia warps time.
